fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • "Given that it was played shortly before his entrance [at Labour's manifesto launch in Birmingham], Gordon Brown's unofficial theme can be assumed to be I'm a Soul Man, famously sung by his late cousin James," said a satirical sketch (Renew the future! 13 April, page 1). For avoidance of confusion: in life, James often featured the song in concert. The version most famed is the Sam & Dave hit. • Two pie diagrams went missing in a set of four depicting results of the latest Guardian/ICM public-opinion survey, which asked questions about Gordon Brown, David Cameron and Nick Clegg (Tories will win, but little enthusiasm for race, ICM finds, 13 April, page 12 ). Results for one of the missing – Who has the best team of potential ministers around him? – were: Cameron 40%, Brown 30%, Clegg 10%. Results for the other – Who is campaigning best for the votes of people like you?– were: Cameron 40%, Brown 22%, Clegg 13%. The remainder answered Don't know, or None of them. • A remembrance of Bodour Osman Abu Affan said that "a highlight of her achievements was the campaign success of the National Union of Sudanese Women ... in securing 25 of the seats for women in the next parliament". This should have read 25%, equivalent to upwards of 100 seats (Other lives, 12 April, page 37). • Elizabeth Taylor and Zsa Zsa Gabor were said to have married and divorced hotelier Conrad Hilton (Pass notes No 2,761, 13 April, page 3, G2). Gabor's Conrad was the father; Taylor's was the son, Conrad "Nicky" Hilton.
